items.title: Trump administration tells states to stop paying full food aid benefits

items.content: The food assistance programme has been caught in a back-and-forth legal battle over funding as the government shutdown drags on.

items.title: Trump administration demands states ‘undo’ full SNAP payments for November amid legal battle
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump's administration is demanding states “undo” full SNAP benefits paid out under judges' orders last week, now that the U.S. Supreme Court has stayed those rulings, marking the latest swing in a seesawing legal battle over the anti-hunger program used by 42 million Americans.
items.content: President Donald Trump's administration is demanding states “undo” full SNAP benefits paid out under judges' orders last week, now that the U.S. Supreme Court has stayed those rulings, marking the latest swing in a seesawing legal battle over the anti-hunger program used by 42 million Americans.

items.title: US flight cancellations rise as Sean Duffy warns travel could reduce to a ‘trickle’
items.standfirst: Over 2,500 flights cancelled as transportation secretary says flight reductions could reach 20% if shutdown persistsFlight cancellations and delays are set to grow as airline passengers across the United States spent the weekend grappling with those issues at major airports nationwide after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated a 4% reduction in air traffic in response to the ongoing federal government shutdown.If the shutdown continues, the FAA has instructed airlines to cut 6% of flights on Tuesday – and to do the same to 10% by 14 November. The transportation secretary, Sean Duffy, has warned that flight reductions could reach 20% if the shutdown persists, and on Sunday he predicted a “substantial” number of people in the US would be unable to celebrate the upcoming holidays with their families if the shutdown wasn’t resolved.The Associated Press and Reuters contributed reporting Continue reading...
items.content: Over 2,500 flights cancelled as transportation secretary says flight reductions could reach 20% if shutdown persistsFlight cancellations and delays are set to grow as airline passengers across the United States spent the weekend grappling with those issues at major airports nationwide after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated a 4% reduction in air traffic in response to the ongoing federal government shutdown.If the shutdown continues, the FAA has instructed airlines to cut 6% of flights on Tuesday – and to do the same to 10% by 14 November. The transportation secretary, Sean Duffy, has warned that flight reductions could reach 20% if the shutdown persists, and on Sunday he predicted a “substantial” number of people in the US would be unable to celebrate the upcoming holidays with their families if the shutdown wasn’t resolved.The Associated Press and Reuters contributed reporting Continue reading...

items.title: US Government shutdown hits 39th day
items.standfirst: Over 1,400 US flights were canceled Saturday after airlines cut traffic due to the federal government shutdown. Nearly 6,000 more were delayed, down from 7,000 on Friday, FlightAware reports. The FAA is reducing capacity at 40 busy airports as unpaid, fatigued air traffic controllers work. Lawmakers remain deadlocked over ending the shutdown, now in its second week. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson reports the latest.
items.content: Over 1,400 US flights were canceled Saturday after airlines cut traffic due to the federal government shutdown. Nearly 6,000 more were delayed, down from 7,000 on Friday, FlightAware reports. The FAA is reducing capacity at 40 busy airports as unpaid, fatigued air traffic controllers work. Lawmakers remain deadlocked over ending the shutdown, now in its second week. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson reports the latest.

items.title: Millions of Americans facing delay after court interrupts SNAP food stamp payments
items.standfirst: The Supreme Court on Friday granted the Trump administration’s emergency appeal to temporarily block a court order to fully fund SNAP food aid payments amid the government shutdown, even though residents in some states already have received the funds. Nicholas Rushworth tells us more.
items.content: The Supreme Court on Friday granted the Trump administration’s emergency appeal to temporarily block a court order to fully fund SNAP food aid payments amid the government shutdown, even though residents in some states already have received the funds. Nicholas Rushworth tells us more.

items.content: Thousands more flights have been delayed or cancelled as the reduction of air travel capacity continues during the federal government shutdown.

items.title: Thousands of US flights cancelled, delayed as government shutdown continues
items.standfirst: The Federal Aviation Administration is temporarily cutting air traffic by 10 percent to maintain safety standards.
items.content: The Federal Aviation Administration is temporarily cutting air traffic by 10 percent to maintain safety standards.

ai_summary: The USDA directed states to immediately stop issuing full food assistance benefits.
The order follows a legal battle over funding for the SNAP program.
The Trump administration is fighting a judge's order to fully fund SNAP benefits.
The Supreme Court stayed rulings that ordered full SNAP payments.
The government shutdown is impacting food assistance for millions of Americans.

clusters.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong slams into Philippines, killing 2 and displacing more than 1 million
clusters.neutral_headline: Super Typhoon Fung-wong Hits Philippines, Causing Damage

items.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong slams into Philippines, killing 2 and displacing more than 1 million
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Fung-wong slammed ashore on Sunday in the northeastern coast of the Philippines, where the massive storm had already left at least two people dead and forced more than a million people to evacuate from flood- and landslide-prone areas, officials said.
items.content: Super Typhoon Fung-wong slammed ashore on Sunday in the northeastern coast of the Philippines, where the massive storm had already left at least two people dead and forced more than a million people to evacuate from flood- and landslide-prone areas, officials said.

items.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong slams into Philippines after displacing 1 million
items.standfirst: The biggest typhoon to threaten the Philippines in years, Fung-wong could cover two-thirds of the archipelago with its 1,118-mile-wide rain and wind band, forecasters said.
items.content: The biggest typhoon to threaten the Philippines in years, Fung-wong could cover two-thirds of the archipelago with its 1,118-mile-wide rain and wind band, forecasters said.

items.title: Super typhoon makes landfall in Philippines as nearly a million evacuated
items.standfirst: Typhoon Fung-wong, with sustained winds of 185 km/h (115mph), made landfall on Sunday evening local time.
items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong, with sustained winds of 185 km/h (115mph), made landfall on Sunday evening local time.

items.title: BBC on Luzon Island as super typhoon hits Philippines
items.standfirst: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall in the Philippines, where more than 900,000 people have been evacuated.
items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall in the Philippines, where more than 900,000 people have been evacuated.

items.title: More than 1 million evacuated in the Philippines as Typhoon Fung-wong draws near
items.standfirst: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon heads for Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated and at least two people killed as flood waters rose in the Philippines before Typhoon Fung-wong’s expected landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon is expected to bring wind and heavy rain to large parts of the archipelago. It comes days after Typhoon Kalmaegi hit the country, killing at least 224 people and leaving another 135 missing. Searches for those still missing had to be suspended on Sunday due to safety concerns for rescue workers. Continue reading...
items.content: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon heads for Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated and at least two people killed as flood waters rose in the Philippines before Typhoon Fung-wong’s expected landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon is expected to bring wind and heavy rain to large parts of the archipelago. It comes days after Typhoon Kalmaegi hit the country, killing at least 224 people and leaving another 135 missing. Searches for those still missing had to be suspended on Sunday due to safety concerns for rescue workers. Continue reading...

items.title: Nearly one million evacuated as Typhoon Fung-wong nears Philippines
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Fung-wong is approaching the Philippines, forcing nearly a million people to evacuate.
items.content: Super Typhoon Fung-wong is approaching the Philippines, forcing nearly a million people to evacuate.

items.title: As Super Typhoon Fung-wong nears, Philippines on edge
items.standfirst: The storm already kills at least one person, disrupts power and forces evacuations of nearly one million people.
items.content: The storm already kills at least one person, disrupts power and forces evacuations of nearly one million people.

items.title: Super Typhoon Fung-wong makes landfall in Philippines, two killed
items.standfirst: New typhoon comes days after Typhoon Kalmaegi left a trail of devastation across the Philippines, killing hundreds.
items.content: New typhoon comes days after Typhoon Kalmaegi left a trail of devastation across the Philippines, killing hundreds.

items.title: Philippines evacuates nearly a million as floodwaters rise and super typhoon nears
items.standfirst: The Philippines evacuated hundreds of thousands of people on Sunday as a super typhoon Fung-wong moved west towards the archipelago nation. The storm is set to bring wind and heavy rain to broad swathes of the country just one week after another typhoon, Kalmaegi, killed hundreds of people in the Philippines.
items.content: The Philippines evacuated hundreds of thousands of people on Sunday as a super typhoon Fung-wong moved west towards the archipelago nation. The storm is set to bring wind and heavy rain to broad swathes of the country just one week after another typhoon, Kalmaegi, killed hundreds of people in the Philippines.

items.title: Nearly a million people evacuate as Super Typhoon Fung-wong threatens the Philippines
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Fung-wong, the biggest storm to threaten the Philippines this year, started battering the country's northeastern coast ahead of landfall on Sunday.
items.content: Super Typhoon Fung-wong, the biggest storm to threaten the Philippines this year, started battering the country's northeastern coast ahead of landfall on Sunday.(Image credit: Malacanang Presidential Communications Office)

items.title: Two dead and a million evacuated as Super Typhoon Fung-wong hits Philippines
items.standfirst: Two people have died and more than one million people evacuated after a storm bearing down on the Philippines intensified into a super typhoon and made landfall on Sunday.
items.content: Two people have died and more than one million people evacuated after a storm bearing down on the Philippines intensified into a super typhoon and made landfall on Sunday.

ai_summary: Typhoon Fung-wong made landfall on the northeastern coast of the Philippines.
At least two people died due to the super typhoon.
Over one million people were evacuated from affected areas.
The storm is expected to bring heavy rain and strong winds.
The typhoon comes after Typhoon Kalmaegi, which killed over 200.

clusters.title: Israel receives body of soldier killed in 2014 in Gaza
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Receives Remains of Soldier Killed in 2014

items.title: Israel receives body of soldier killed in 2014 in Gaza
items.standfirst: The Israeli military confirmed the soldier's body had been returned from Gaza after 11 years on Sunday.
items.content: The Israeli military confirmed the soldier's body had been returned from Gaza after 11 years on Sunday.

items.title: Israel receives remains of an Israeli soldier who was killed in Gaza in 2014
items.standfirst: Hamas said it found the body of the soldier, Hadar Goldin, in a tunnel in the enclave's southernmost city of Rafah on Saturday. Goldin was killed on Aug. 1, 2014.
items.content: Hamas said it found the body of the soldier, Hadar Goldin, in a tunnel in the enclave's southernmost city of Rafah on Saturday. Goldin was killed on Aug. 1, 2014.

items.title: Israel receives remains of soldier killed in Gaza in 2014
items.standfirst: Body identified as Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin with the remains of four other deceased captives still in Gaza.
items.content: Body identified as Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin with the remains of four other deceased captives still in Gaza.

items.title: Israel receives remains of hostage that Hamas says is IDF soldier killed in 2014
items.standfirst: Hadar Goldin was killed on Aug. 1, 2014, two hours after a ceasefire took effect ending that year's war between Israel and Hamas.
items.content: Hadar Goldin was killed on Aug. 1, 2014, two hours after a ceasefire took effect ending that year's war between Israel and Hamas.(Image credit: Mahmoud Illean)

items.title: Israel receives the remains of a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014
items.standfirst: Israel on Sunday confirmed it had received the remains of Hadar Goldin, a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014. The return of Goldin's remains marked the end of an 11-year effort by his family and closed a painful chapter in the country’s long conflict with Hamas.
items.content: Israel on Sunday confirmed it had received the remains of Hadar Goldin, a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014. The return of Goldin's remains marked the end of an 11-year effort by his family and closed a painful chapter in the country’s long conflict with Hamas.

ai_summary: Israel received the remains of soldier Hadar Goldin from Gaza.
Goldin was killed in 2014 during the war between Israel and Hamas.
Hamas said it found Goldin's body in a tunnel in Rafah.
The remains of four other deceased captives are still in Gaza.
The return of the remains ended an 11-year effort by Goldin's family.

clusters.title: BBC director resigns after row over Trump documentary edit
clusters.neutral_headline: BBC Director Resigns After Criticism of Trump Speech

items.title: BBC director resigns after row over Trump documentary edit
items.standfirst: The director general of Britain's BBC, Tim Davie, and the chief executive of news, Deborah Turness, have stepped down following criticism over bias at the corporation, including in the way it edited a speech by US President Donald Trump.
items.content: The director general of Britain's BBC, Tim Davie, and the chief executive of news, Deborah Turness, have stepped down following criticism over bias at the corporation, including in the way it edited a speech by US President Donald Trump.

items.title: BBC boss Tim Davie resigns
items.standfirst: Exit comes after broadcaster was accused of bias on Trump, the Gaza war and coverage of transgender rights
items.content: Exit comes after broadcaster was accused of bias on Trump, the Gaza war and coverage of transgender rights

items.title: BBC director resigns after criticism of the broadcaster's editing of a Trump speech
items.standfirst: The BBC said that director-general Tim Davie and head of news Deborah Turness have resigned after criticism of the broadcaster's editing of a speech by U.S. President Donald Trump.
items.content: The BBC said that director-general Tim Davie and head of news Deborah Turness have resigned after criticism of the broadcaster's editing of a speech by U.S. President Donald Trump.(Image credit: Hannah McKay)

items.title: Tim Davie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverage
items.standfirst: Davie tells staff departure was ‘my own decision’ but it comes with the BBC preparing to apologise for the way it edited a Trump speechTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.In a shock move, Davie said his depature was his own, but comes with the BBC preparing to apologise for the way the broadcaster edited a Donald Trump speech. Continue reading...
items.content: Davie tells staff departure was ‘my own decision’ but it comes with the BBC preparing to apologise for the way it edited a Trump speechTim Davie, the BBC’s director general, and the head of BBC News have resigned after a former adviser to the corporation accused it of “serious and systemic” bias in its coverage of issues including Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights.In a shock move, Davie said his depature was his own, but comes with the BBC preparing to apologise for the way the broadcaster edited a Donald Trump speech. Continue reading...

ai_summary: BBC Director-General Tim Davie resigned after criticism.
The criticism concerned the editing of a Donald Trump speech.
Head of News Deborah Turness also resigned.
The BBC is preparing to apologize for the editing of the speech.
Accusations of bias in coverage of Trump, Gaza, and trans rights.

items.title: Review to look at role of mental health issues in UK youth unemployment
items.standfirst: Former health secretary Alan Milburn’s review is exploring reasons for rising inactivity among young people Feature: how Dudley became centre of youth jobs crisis The role of mental health issues and disability in youth unemployment will be examined by the former Labour health secretary Alan…
items.content: Former health secretary Alan Milburn’s review is exploring reasons for rising inactivity among young people Feature: how Dudley became centre of youth jobs crisis The role of mental health issues and disability in youth unemployment will be examined by the former Labour health secretary Alan…

items.title: Review to look at role of mental health issues in UK youth unemployment
items.standfirst: Former health secretary Alan Milburn’s review is exploring reasons for rising inactivity among young peopleFeature: how Dudley became centre of youth jobs crisisThe role of mental health issues and disability in youth unemployment will be examined by the former Labour health secretary Alan Milburn as part of a review looking into rising inactivity among Britain’s young people.Nearly a million people aged 16 to 24 are not in education, employment or training, often described with the acronym Neets. Milburn will look at ways to avoid people becoming trapped as Neets and the findings will be published in the summer. Continue reading...
items.content: Former health secretary Alan Milburn’s review is exploring reasons for rising inactivity among young peopleFeature: how Dudley became centre of youth jobs crisisThe role of mental health issues and disability in youth unemployment will be examined by the former Labour health secretary Alan Milburn as part of a review looking into rising inactivity among Britain’s young people.Nearly a million people aged 16 to 24 are not in education, employment or training, often described with the acronym Neets. Milburn will look at ways to avoid people becoming trapped as Neets and the findings will be published in the summer. Continue reading...

items.title: Inquiry to review rise in young people not working or studying
items.standfirst: Former Labour Health Secretary Alan Milburn will lead the investigation, with conclusions set to be published next summer.
items.content: Former Labour Health Secretary Alan Milburn will lead the investigation, with conclusions set to be published next summer.

ai_summary: Alan Milburn will lead a review of youth unemployment in the UK.
The review will examine the role of mental health issues.
The findings will be published next summer.
Nearly a million young people are not in education or employment.
The review will look at ways to avoid people becoming NEETs.

items.title: West Virginia Gov. Patrick Morrisey says National Guard has been activated to food banks
items.standfirst: West Virginia Gov. Patrick Morrisey, whose state has more than 270,000 people using SNAP benefits, said on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that his administration is "working by activating the Guard and putting resources at the food banks." "Our people are hurting right now, and I'm doing everything I can to solve the problems while Washington bickers," Morrisey said.
items.content: West Virginia Gov. Patrick Morrisey, whose state has more than 270,000 people using SNAP benefits, said on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that his administration is "working by activating the Guard and putting resources at the food banks." "Our people are hurting right now, and I'm doing everything I can to solve the problems while Washington bickers," Morrisey said.

items.title: Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill says New Jerseyans want to see an "agenda to get their costs down"
items.standfirst: New Jersey Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill said on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that her state's residents elected her because they want "to see an agenda to get their costs down, and something that was going to take place quickly. As I said, you know, I'm not writing a strongly-worded letter. I'm not doing a 10-year plan."
items.content: New Jersey Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill said on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that her state's residents elected her because they want "to see an agenda to get their costs down, and something that was going to take place quickly. As I said, you know, I'm not writing a strongly-worded letter. I'm not doing a 10-year plan."

items.title: Virginia Gov.-elect Abigail Spanberger says state heading toward "energy crisis"
items.standfirst: Virginia Gov.-elect Abigail Spanberger, a Democrat who was elected last week, said on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that amid increased energy costs in her state, there have been some bad energy policies in some of our neighboring states that have driven up prices, particularly in southwest Virginia." But, she added, "looking towards the future, we have to be clear eyed about the fact that we will have an energy crisis headed into the future."
items.content: Virginia Gov.-elect Abigail Spanberger, a Democrat who was elected last week, said on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that amid increased energy costs in her state, there have been some bad energy policies in some of our neighboring states that have driven up prices, particularly in southwest Virginia." But, she added, "looking towards the future, we have to be clear eyed about the fact that we will have an energy crisis headed into the future."

items.title: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore criticizes White House for "intentional chaos" on shutdown funding
items.standfirst: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, a Democrat, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that there has been "intentional chaos" from the Trump administration as it says it cannot fund SNAP benefits amid the shutdown. "They got money for everything but when it's to supporting the people, that's now when they are crying, well, we are broke and that's not what the law requires us to do," Moore said.
items.content: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, a Democrat, told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that there has been "intentional chaos" from the Trump administration as it says it cannot fund SNAP benefits amid the shutdown. "They got money for everything but when it's to supporting the people, that's now when they are crying, well, we are broke and that's not what the law requires us to do," Moore said.

items.title: Top Trump economic adviser says there could be a "negative quarter" if shutdown drags on
items.standfirst: White House National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that the fourth quarter could be a "negative quarter" if the government shutdown drags on through Thanksgiving. He added that military paychecks could stop on Nov. 15, and while SNAP benefits are being administered under the law, but "it's really, really pushing the boundaries of the law."

items.title: Last Christmas, you gave us first class: Royal Mail turns Scrooge with gift to staff of second-class stamps
items.standfirst: Switch comes amid first festive season since Daniel Křetínský’s takeover of parent company IDS Royal Mail says that it has “delivered Christmas” for more than 500 years, but this year many workers have been left feeling less than festive after the company downgraded a small gift to workers to…
items.content: Switch comes amid first festive season since Daniel Křetínský’s takeover of parent company IDS Royal Mail says that it has “delivered Christmas” for more than 500 years, but this year many workers have been left feeling less than festive after the company downgraded a small gift to workers to…

items.title: Last Christmas, you gave us first class: Royal Mail turns Scrooge with gift to staff of second-class stamps
items.standfirst: Switch comes amid first festive season since Daniel Křetínský’s takeover of parent company IDSRoyal Mail says that it has “delivered Christmas” for more than 500 years, but this year many workers have been left feeling less than festive after the company downgraded a small gift to workers to second class.The postal service, which traces its history back to the appointment of a “master of the posts” by Henry VIII in 1516, has given workers a collection of 50 Christmas stamps to recognise their work over the busiest time of year. In previous years, including in 2024, workers have received a book of 50 or 100 first-class stamps, but that has quietly been switched to second class this year. Continue reading...
items.content: Switch comes amid first festive season since Daniel Křetínský’s takeover of parent company IDSRoyal Mail says that it has “delivered Christmas” for more than 500 years, but this year many workers have been left feeling less than festive after the company downgraded a small gift to workers to second class.The postal service, which traces its history back to the appointment of a “master of the posts” by Henry VIII in 1516, has given workers a collection of 50 Christmas stamps to recognise their work over the busiest time of year. In previous years, including in 2024, workers have received a book of 50 or 100 first-class stamps, but that has quietly been switched to second class this year. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Royal Mail gave staff second-class stamps as a Christmas gift.
This is the first festive season since a takeover.
In previous years, staff received first-class stamps.
The change has left some workers feeling less than festive.
Royal Mail has a long history, dating back to 1516.

items.title: Iraq: Early parliament polls begin with security forces and displaced people able to vote today
items.standfirst: Members of Iraq’s security forces, along with internally displaced citizens, began voting in the parliamentary elections on Sunday - the sixth since the 2003 US-led invasion that toppled Saddam Hussein. Polls opened at 7 am for 1.3 million security personnel across 809 polling centers and will close at 6 pm before they are deployed to provide security on the main election day on Tuesday. France24 correspondent Lina Malers reports the latest from Baghdad, Iraq.
items.content: Members of Iraq’s security forces, along with internally displaced citizens, began voting in the parliamentary elections on Sunday - the sixth since the 2003 US-led invasion that toppled Saddam Hussein. Polls opened at 7 am for 1.3 million security personnel across 809 polling centers and will close at 6 pm before they are deployed to provide security on the main election day on Tuesday. France24 correspondent Lina Malers reports the latest from Baghdad, Iraq.
